References Created by Manually Sharing Objects

When you share a folder or item from one location to another (whether in the same view or not), an additional reference is created for that object in the new location. The reference for the new folder or item becomes a child of the reference for the folder or item that was shared.

StarTeam does not differentiate between references based on the events that caused them to be created. However, you can tell by looking at the reference hierarchy that one reference is the source of another reference, because the second reference is indented under it. You can also tell, because the references are in the same view, that a manual share or move occurred. (If a child view was created, the two references would be in different views.)

Although a shared folder or item can branch, it may never do so. Regardless, some subset of its history is part of the history of the original folder or item.

Floating Upwards and Downwards

If a view hierarchy is deep (the root view has grandchildren, great- grandchildren, and so on), the use of branching, floating views can cause a great deal of confusion. Suppose all the views except the root view branch and float. At its new location, the folder or item that you moved can float:

  • Up the view hierarchy from the recipient view to the root view.

  • Down to all the recipient view’s children, grandchildren, and so on.

  • From the recipient view’s parents, grandparents, and so on, to all of their other children.

This situation can produce a reference to the folder or item in the new location in every view in the project view hierarchy. Many of those views may already have a reference to the folder or item in its previous location.
